For when would you my Lord, or you, or you, Haue found the ground of ſtudies excellence, Without the beauty of a womans face; From womens eyes this doƈtrine I deriue, They are the Ground, the Bookes, the Achadems, From whence doth ſpring the true Promethean fire. Why, vniuerſall plodding poyſons vp The nimble ſpirits in the arteries, As motion and long during aƈtion tyres The ſinnowy vigour of the trauailer. Now for not looking on a womans face, You haue in that forſworne the vſe of eyes: And ſtudie too, the cauſer of your vow. For where is any Author in the world, Teaches ſuch beauty as a womans eye: Learning is but an adiunƈt to our ſelfe, And where we are, our Learning likewiſe is. Then when our ſelues we ſee in Ladies eyes, With our ſelues. Dœ we not likewiſe ſee our learning there? O we haue made a Vow to ſtudie, Lords, And in that vow we haue forſworne our Bookes: For when would you (my Leege) or you, or you? In leaden contemplation haue found out Such fiery Numbers as the prompting eyes, Of beauties tutors haue inrich’d you with: Other ſlow Arts intirely keepe the braine: And therefore finding barraine praƈtizers, Scarce ſhew a harueſt of their heauy toyle. But Loue firſt learned in a Ladies eyes, Liues not alone emured in the braine: But with the motion of all elements, Courſes as ſwift as thought in euery power, And giues to euery power a double power, Aboue their funƈtions and their offices. It addes a precious ſeeing to the eye: A Louers eyes will gaze an Eagle blinde. A Louers eare will heare the loweſt ſound. When the ſuſpicious head of theft is ſtopt. Loues feeling is more ſoft and ſenſible, Then are the tender hornes of Cockle Snayles. Loues tongue proues dainty, Bachus groſſe in taſte, For Valour, is not Loue a Hercules? Still climing trees in the Heſporides. Subtill as Sphinx, as ſweet and muſicall, As bright Apollo’s Lute, ſtrung with his haire. And when Loue ſpeakes, the voyce of all the Gods, Make heauen drowſie with the harmonie. Neuer durſt Pœt touch a pen to write, Vntill his Inke were tempred with Loues ſighes: O then his lines would rauiſh ſauage eares, And plant in Tyrants milde humilitie. From womens eyes this doƈtrine I deriue. They ſparcle ſtill the right promethean fire, They are the Bookes, the Arts, the Achademes, That ſhew, containe, and nouriſh all the world. Elſe none at all in ought proues excellent. Then fooles you were theſe women to forſweare: Or keeping what is ſworne, you will proue fooles, For Wiſedomes ſake, a word that all men loue: Or for Loues ſake, a word that loues all men. Or for Mens ſake, the author of theſe Women: Or Womens ſake, by whom we men are Men. Let’s once looſe our oathes to finde our ſelues, Or elſe we looſe our ſelues, to keepe our oathes: It is religion to be thus forſworne. For Charity it ſelfe fulfills the Law: And who can ſeuer loue from Charity.
Kin. Saint Cupid then, and Souldiers to the field.
Ber. Aduance your ſtandards, & vpon them Lords, Pell, mell, downe with them: but be firſt aduis’d, In confliƈt that you get the Sunne of them.
Long. Now to plaine dealing, Lay theſe glozes by, Shall we reſolue to wœ theſe girles of France?
Kin. And winne them too, therefore let vs deuiſe, Some entertainment for them in their Tents.
Ber. Firſt from the Park let vs conduƈt them thither, Then homeward euery man attach the hand Of his faire Miſtreſſe, in the afternoone We will with ſome ſtrange paſtime ſolace them: Such as the ſhortneſſe of the time can ſhape, For Reuels, Dances, Maskes, and merry houres, Fore-runne faire Loue, ſtrewing her way with flowres.
Kin. Away, away, no time ſhall be omitted, That will be time, and may by vs be fitted.
Ber. Alone, alone ſowed Cockell, reap’d no Corne, And Iuſtice alwaies whirles in equall meaſure: Light Wenches may proue plagues to men forſworne, If ſo, our Copper buyes no better treaſure.
Exeunt.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the Pedant, Curate and Dull.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedant.
SPEECH.LINE: Satis quid ſufficit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Curat.
SPEECH.LINE: I praiſe God for you ſir, your reaſons at dinner
haue beene ſharpe & ſententious: pleaſant without ſcur-
rillity, witty without affeƈtion, audacious without im-
pudency, learned without opinion, and ſtrange without
hereſie: I did conuerſe this quondam day with a compa-
nion of the Kings, who is intituled, nominated, or called,
Don Adriano de Armatho.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: Noui hominum tanquam te, His humour is lofty,
his diſcourſe peremptorie: his tongue filed, his eye
ambitious, his gate maieſticall, and his generall behaui-
our vaine, ridiculous, and thraſonicall. He is too picked,
too ſpruce, too affeƈted, too odde, as it were, too pere-
grinat, as I may call it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Curat.
SPEECH.LINE: A moſt ſingular and choiſe Epithat,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: He draweth out the thred of his verboſitie, fi-
ner then the ſtaple of his argument. I abhor ſuch pha-
naticall phantaſims, ſuch inſociable and poynt deuiſe
companions, ſuch rackers of ortagriphie, as to ſpeake
dout fine, when he ſhould ſay doubt; det, when he ſhold
pronounce debt; debt, not det: he clepeth a Calf, Caufe:
halfe, haufe: neighbour vocatur nebour; neigh abreuiated
ne: this is abhominable, which he would call abhomi-
nable it inſinuateth me of infamie: ne inteligis domine, to
make franticke, lunaticke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cura.
SPEECH.LINE: Laus deo, bene intelligo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: Bome boon for boon preſcian, a little ſcratcht, ’twil
ſerue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Curat.
SPEECH.LINE: Vides ne quis venit?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: Video, & gaudio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Chirra.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: Quari Chirra, not Sirra?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Men of peace well incountred.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: Moſt millitarie ſir ſalutation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: They haue beene at a great feaſt of Languages,
and ſtolne the ſcraps.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: O they haue liu’d long on the almes-basket of
words. I maruell thy M. hath not eaten thee for a word,
for thou art not ſo long by the head as honorificabilitu-
dinitatibus: Thou art eaſier ſwallowed then a flapdra-
gon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, the peale begins.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Mounſier, are you not lettred?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, yes, he teaches boyes the Horne-booke:
What is Ab ſpeld backward with the horn on his head?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: Ba, puericia with a horne added.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: Ba moſt ſeely Sheepe, with a horne: you heare
his learning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: Quis quis, thou Conſonant?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: The laſt of the fiue Vowels if You repeat them,
or the fift if I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: I will repeat them: a e I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: The Sheepe, the other two concludes it o u.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Now by the ſalt waue of the mediteranium, a
ſweet tutch, a quicke venewe of wit, ſnip ſnap, quick &
home, it reioyceth my intelleƈt, true wit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Offered by a childe to an olde man: which is
wit-old.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: What is the figure? What is the figure?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Hornes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou diſputes like an Infant: gœ whip thy
Gigge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: Lend me your Horne to make one, and I will
whip about your Infamie vnum cita a gigge of a Cuck-
olds horne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: And I had but one penny in the world, thou
ſhouldſt haue it to buy Ginger bread: Hold, there is the
very Remuneration I had of thy Maiſter, thou halfpenny
purſe of wit, thou Pidgeon-egge of diſcretion. O & the
heauens were ſo pleaſed, that thou wert but my Baſtard;
What a ioyfull father wouldſt thou make mee? Gœ to,
thou haſt it ad dungil, at the fingers ends, as they ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh I ſmell falſe Latine, dunghel for vnguem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Artſ-man preambulat, we will bee ſingled from
the barbarous. Do you not educate youth at the Charg-
houſe on the top of the Mountaine?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: Or Mons the hill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: At your ſweet pleaſure, for the Mountaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: I dœ ſans queſtion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bra.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, it is the Kings moſt ſweet pleaſure and af-
feƈtion, to congratulate the Princeſſe at her Pauilion, in
the poſteriors of this day, which the rude multitude call
the after-noone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: The poſterior of the day, moſt generous ſir, is lia-
ble, congruent, and meaſurable for the after-noone: the
word is well culd, choſe, ſweet, and apt I dœ aſſure you
ſir, I dœ aſſure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, the King is a noble Gentleman, and my fa-
miliar, I dœ aſſure ye very good friend: for what is in-
ward betweene vs, let it paſſe. I dœ beſeech thee re-
member thy curteſie. I beſeech thee apparell thy head:
and among other importunate & moſt ſerious deſignes,
and of great import indeed too: but let that paſſe, for I
muſt tell thee it will pleaſe his Grace (by the world)
ſometime to leane vpon my poore ſhoulder, and with
his royall finger thus dallie with my excrement, with my
muſtachio: but ſweet heart let that paſſe. By the world
I recount no fable, ſome certaine ſpeciall honours it
pleaſeth his greatneſſe to impart to Armado a Souldier,
a man of trauell, that hath ſeene the world: but let that
paſſe; the very all of all is: but ſweet heart I do implore
ſecrecie, that the King would haue mee preſent the
Princeſſe (ſweet chucke) with ſome delightfull oſtenta-
tion, or ſhow, or pageant, or anticke, or fire-worke:
Now, vnderſtanding that the Curate and your ſweet ſelf
are good at ſuch eruptions, and ſodaine breaking out of
myrth (as it were) I haue acquainted you withall, to
the end to craue your aſſiſtance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, you ſhall preſent before her the Nine Wor-
thies. Sir Holofernes, as concerning ſome entertainment
of time, ſome ſhow in the poſterior of this day, to bee
rendred by our aſſiſtants the Kings command: and this
moſt gallant, illuſtrate and learned Gentleman, before
the Princeſſe: I ſay none ſo fit as to preſent the Nine
Worthies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Curat.
SPEECH.LINE: Where will you finde men worthy enough to
preſent them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: Ioſua, your ſelfe: my ſelfe, and this gallant gen-
tleman Iudas Machabeus; this Swaine (becauſe of his
great limme or ioynt) ſhall paſſe Pompey the great,
the Page Hercules.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon ſir, error: He is not quantitie enough
for that Worthies thumb, hee is not ſo big as the end of
his Club.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I haue audience: he ſhall preſent Hercu-
les in minoritie: his enter and exit ſhall bee ſtrangling a
Snake; and I will haue an Apologie for that purpoſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: An excellent deuice: ſo if any of the audience
hiſſe, you may cry, Well done Hercules, now thou cru-
ſheſt the Snake; that is the way to make an offence gra-
cious, though few haue the grace to dœ it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: For the reſt of the Worthies?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: I will play three my ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: Thrice worthy Gentleman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I tell you a thing?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: We attend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: We will haue, if this fadge not, an Antique. I
beſeech you follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: Via good-man Dull, thou haſt ſpoken no word
all this while.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dull.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor vnderſtood none neither ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: Alone, we will employ thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dull.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile make one in a dance, or ſo: or I will play on
the taber to the Worthies, & let them dance the hey.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped
SPEECH.LINE: Moſt Dull, honeſt Dull, to our ſport away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet hearts we ſhall be rich ere we depart,
If fairings come thus plentifully in.
A Lady wal’d about with Diamonds: Look you, what I
haue from the louing King.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſa.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, came nothing elſe along with that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing but this: yes as much loue in Rime,
As would be cram’d vp in a ſheet of paper
Writ on both ſides the leafe, margent and all,
That he was faine to ſeale on Cupids name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſa.
SPEECH.LINE: That was the way to make his god-head wax:
For he hath beene fiue thouſand yeeres a Boy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kath.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and a ſhrewd vnhappy gallowes too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: You’ll nere be friends with him, a kild your ſiſter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kath.
SPEECH.LINE: He made her melancholy, ſad, and heauy, and
ſo ſhe died: had ſhe beene Light like you, of ſuch a mer-
rie nimble ſtirring ſpirit, ſhe might a bin a Grandam ere
ſhe died. And ſo may you: For a light heart liues long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: What’s your darke meaning mouſe, of this light
word?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: A light condition in a beauty darke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: We need more light to finde your meaning out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: You’ll marre the light by taking it in ſnuffe:
Therefore Ile darkely end the argument.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Look what you dœ, you dœ it ſtil i’th darke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: So do not you, for you are a light Wench.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed I waigh not you, and therefore light.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ka.
SPEECH.LINE: You waigh me not, O that’s you care not for me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Great reaſon: for paſt care, is ſtill paſt cure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Well bandied both, a ſet of Wit well played.
But Roſaline, you haue a Fauour too?
Who ſent it? and what is it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: I would you knew.
And if my face were but as faire as yours,
My Fauour were as great, be witneſſe this.
Nay, I haue Verſes too, I thanke Berowne,
The numbers true, and were the numbring too.
I were the faireſt goddeſſe on the ground.
I am compar’d to twenty thouſand fairs.
O he hath drawne my pi’ture in his letter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Any thing like?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Much in the letters, nothing in the praiſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Beauteous as Incke: a good concluſion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: Faire as a text B. in a Coppie booke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Ware penſals. How? Let me not die your debtor,
My red Dominicall, my golden letter.
O that your face were full of œs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: A Pox of that ieſt, and I beſhrew all Shrowes:
But Katherine, what was ſent to you
From faire Dumaine?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: Madame, this Gloue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Did he not ſend you twaine?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes Madame: and moreouer,
Some thouſand Verſes of a faithfull Louer.
A huge tranſlation of hypocriſie,
Vildly compiled, profound ſimplicitie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: This, and these Pearls, to me ſent Longauile.
The Letter is too long by halfe a mile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke no leſſe: Doſt thou wiſh in heart
The Chaine were longer, and the Letter ſhort.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: I, or I would theſe hands might neuer part.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quee.
SPEECH.LINE: We are wiſe girles to mocke our Louers ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: They are worſe fooles to purchaſe mocking ſo.
That ſame Berowne ile torture ere I gœ.
O that I knew he were but in by th’weeke,
How I would make him fawne, and begge, and ſeeke,
And wait the ſeaſon, and obſerue the times,
And ſpend his prodigall wits in booteles rimes,
And ſhape his ſeruice wholly to my deuice,
And make him proud to make me proud that ieſts.
So pertaunt like would I o’reſway his ſtate,
That he ſhold be my foole, and I his fate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: None are ſo ſurely caught, when they are catcht,
As Wit turn’d foole, follie in Wiſedome hatch’d:
Hath wiſedoms warrant, and the helpe of Schoole,
And Wits owne grace to grace a learned Foole?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: The bloud of youth burns not with ſuch exceſſe,
As grauities reuolt to wantons be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Follie in Fooles beares not ſo ſtrong a note,
As fool’ry in the Wiſe, when Wit doth dote:
Since all the power thereof it doth apply,
To proue by Wit, worth in ſimplicitie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere comes Boyet, and mirth in his face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: O I am ſtab’d with laughter, Wher’s her Grace?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy newes Boyet?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Prepare Madame, prepare.
Arme Wenches arme, incounters mounted are,
Againſt your Peace, Loue doth approach, diſguis’d:
Armed in arguments, you’ll be ſurpriz’d.
Muſter your Wits, ſtand in your owne defence,
Or hide your heads like Cowards, and flie hence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Saint Dennis to S. Cupid: What are they,
That charge their breath againſt vs? Say ſcout ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Vnder the coole ſhade of a Siccamore,
I thought to cloſe mine eyes ſome halfe an houre:
When lo to interrupt my purpos’d reſt,
Toward that ſhade I might behold addreſt,
The King and his companions: warely
I ſtole into a neighbour thicket by,
And ouer-heard, what you ſhall ouer-heare:
That by and by diſguis’d they will be heere.
Their Herald is a pretty knauiſh Page:
That well by heart hath con’d his embaſſage,
Aƈtion and accent did they teach him there.
Thus muſt thou ſpeake, and thus thy body beare.
And euer and anon they made a doubt,
Preſence maieſticall would put him out:
For quoth the King, an Angell ſhalt thou ſee:
Yet feare not thou, but ſpeake audaciouſly.
The Boy reply’d, An Angell is not euill:
I ſhould haue fear’d her, had ſhe beene a deuill.
With that all laugh’d, and clap’d him on the ſhoulder,
Making the bold wagg by their praiſes bolder.
One rub’d his elbœ thus, and fleer’d, and ſwore,
A better ſpeech was neuer ſpoke before.
Another with his finger and his thumb,
Cry’d via, we will doo’t, come what will come.
The third he caper’d and cried, All gœs well.
The fourth turn’d on the tœ, and downe he fell:
With that they all did tumble on the ground,
With ſuch a zelous laughter ſo profound,
That in this ſpleene ridiculous appeares,
To checke their folly paſſions ſolemne teares.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Que.
SPEECH.LINE: But what, but what, come they to viſit vs?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: They do, they do; and are apparel’d thus,
Like Muſcouites; or Ruſſians, as I geſſe.
Their purpoſe is to parlee, to court, and dance,
And euery one his Loue-feat will aduance,
Vnto his ſeuerall Miſtreſſe: which they’ll know
By fauours ſeuerall, which they did beſtow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Queen.
SPEECH.LINE: And will they ſo? the Gallants ſhall be taskt:
For Ladies; we will euery one be maskt,
And not a man of them ſhall haue the grace
Deſpight of ſute, to ſee a Ladies face.
Hold Roſaline, this Fauour thou ſhalt weare,
And then the King will court thee for his Deare:
Hold, take thou this my ſweet, and giue me thine,
So ſhall Berowne take me for Roſaline.
And change your Fauours too, ſo ſhall your Loues
Woo contrary, deceiu’d by theſe remoues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſa.
SPEECH.LINE: Come on then, weare the fauours moſt in ſight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kath.
SPEECH.LINE: But in this changing, What is your intent?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Queen.
SPEECH.LINE: The effeƈt of my intent is to croſſe theirs:
They dœ it but in mocking merriment,
And mocke for mocke is onely my intent.
Their ſeuerall counſels they vnboſome ſhall,
To Loues miſtooke, and ſo be mockt withall.
Vpon the next occaſion that we meete,
With Viſages diſplayd to talke and greete.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: But ſhall we dance, if they deſire vs too’t?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quee.
SPEECH.LINE: No, to the death we will not moue a foot,
Nor to their pen’d ſpeech render we no grace:
But while ’tis ſpoke, each turne away his face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Why that contempt will kill the keepers heart,
And quite diuorce his memory from his part.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quee.
SPEECH.LINE: Therefore I dœ it, and I make no doubt,
The reſt will ere come in, if he be out.
Theres no ſuch ſport, as ſport by ſport orethrowne:
To make theirs ours, and ours none but our owne.
So ſhall we ſtay mocking entended game,
And they well mockt, depart away with ſhame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: The Trompet ſounds, be maskt, the maskers
come.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Black moores with muſicke, the Boy with a ſpeech, and the reſt of the Lords diſguiſed.

LINE.ITALIC: All haile, the richeſt Beauties on the earth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Beauties no richer then rich Taffata.

LINE.ITALIC: A holy parcell of the faireſt dames that euer turn’d
their backes to mortall viewes.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: The Ladies turne their backes to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Their eyes villaine, their eyes.

LINE.ITALIC: That euer turn’d their eyes to mortall viewes.
Out

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: True, out indeed.

LINE.ITALIC: Out of your fauours heauenly ſpirits vouchſafe
Not to beholde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Once to behold, rogue.

LINE.ITALIC: Once to behold with your Sunne beamed eyes,
With your Sunne beamed eyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: They will not anſwer to that Epythite,
you were beſt call it Daughter beamed eyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: They do not marke me, and that brings me out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bero.
SPEECH.LINE: Is this your perfeƈtneſſe? be gon you rogue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſa.
SPEECH.LINE: What would theſe ſtrangers?
Know their mindes Boyet.
If they dœ ſpeake our language, ’tis our will
That ſome plaine man recount their purpoſes.
Know what they would?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boyet.
SPEECH.LINE: What would you with the Princes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing but peace, and gentle viſitation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: What would they, ſay they?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing but peace, and gentle viſitation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſa.
SPEECH.LINE: Why that they haue, and bid them ſo be gon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: She ſaies you haue it, and you may be gon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Say to her we haue meaſur’d many miles,
To tread a Meaſure with you on the graſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: They ſay that they haue meaſur’d many a mile,
To tread a Meaſure with you on this graſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſa.
SPEECH.LINE: It is not ſo. Aske them how many inches
Is in one mile? If they haue meaſur’d manie,
The meaſure then of one is eaſlie told.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: If to come hither, you haue meaſur’d miles,
And many miles: the Princeſſe bids you tell,
How many inches doth fill vp one mile?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Tell her we meaſure them by weary ſteps.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: She heares her ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſa.
SPEECH.LINE: How manie wearie ſteps,
Of many wearie miles you haue ore-gone,
Are numbred in the trauell of one mile?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bero.
SPEECH.LINE: We number nothing that we ſpend for you,
Our dutie is ſo rich, ſo infinite,
That we may dœ it ſtill without accompt.
Vouchſafe to ſhew the ſunſhine of your face,
That we (like ſauages) may worſhip it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſa.
SPEECH.LINE: My face is but a Moone and clouded too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Bleſſed are clouds, to dœ as ſuch clouds do.
Vouchſafe bright Moone, and theſe thy ſtars to ſhine,
(Thoſe clouds remooued) vpon our waterie eyne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſa.
SPEECH.LINE: O vaine peticioner, beg a greater matter,
Thou now requeſts but Mooneſhine in the water.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Then in our meaſure, vouchſafe but one change.
Thou bidſt me begge, this begging is not ſtrange.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſa.
SPEECH.LINE: Play muſicke then: nay you muſt dœ it ſoone.
Not yet no dance: thus change I like the Moone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Will you not dance? How come you thus e-
ſtranged?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſa.
SPEECH.LINE: You tooke the Moone at full, but now ſhee’s
changed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet ſtill ſhe is the Moone, and I the Man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſa.
SPEECH.LINE: The muſick playes, vouchſafe ſome motion to
it: Our eares vouchſafe it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: But your legges ſhould dœ it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Since you are ſtrangers, & come here by chance,
Wee’ll not be nice, take hands, we will not dance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Why take you hands then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſa.
SPEECH.LINE: Onelie to part friends.
Curtſie ſweet hearts, and ſo the Meaſure ends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: More meaſure of this meaſure, be not nice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſa.
SPEECH.LINE: We can afford no more at ſuch a price.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Priſe your ſelues: What buyes your companie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſa.
SPEECH.LINE: Your abſence onelie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: That can neuer be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſa.
SPEECH.LINE: Then cannot we be bought: and ſo adue,
Twice to your Viſore, and halfe once to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: If you denie to dance, let’s hold more chat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: In priuate then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: I am beſt pleas’d with that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Be.
SPEECH.LINE: White handed Miſtris, one ſweet word with thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Hony, and Milke, and Suger: there is three.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay then two treyes, an if you grow ſo nice
Methegline, Wort, and Malmſey; well runne dice:
There’s halfe a dozen ſweets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Seuenth ſweet adue, ſince you can cogg,
Ile play no more with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: One word in ſecret.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Let it not be ſweet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou greeu’ſt my gall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Gall, bitter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Therefore meete.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: Will you vouchſafe with me to change a word?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Name it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: Faire Ladie:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Say you ſo? Faire Lord:
Take you that for your faire Lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: Pleaſe it you,
As much in priuate, and Ile bid adieu.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: What, was your vizard made without a tong?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Long.
SPEECH.LINE: I know the reaſon Ladie why you aske.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: O for your reaſon, quickly ſir, I long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Long.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue a double tongue within your mask,
And would affoord my ſpeechleſſe vizard halfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Veale quoth the Dutch-man: is not Veale a
Calfe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Long.
SPEECH.LINE: A Calfe faire Ladie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: No, a faire Lord Calfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Long.
SPEECH.LINE: Let’s part the word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: No, Ile not be your halfe:
Take all and weane it, it may proue an Oxe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Long.
SPEECH.LINE: Looke how you but your ſelfe in theſe ſharpe
mockes.
Will you giue hornes chaſt Ladie? Do not ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Then die a Calfe before your horns do grow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lon.
SPEECH.LINE: One word in priuate with you ere I die.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Bleat ſoftly then, the Butcher heares you cry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boyet.
SPEECH.LINE: The tongues of mocking wenches are as keen
As is the Razors edge, inuiſible:
Cutting a ſmaller haire then may be ſeene,
Aboue the ſenſe of ſence ſo ſenſible:
Seemeth their conference, their conceits haue wings,
Fleeter then arrows, bullets wind, thoght, ſwifter things

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſa.
SPEECH.LINE: Not one word more my maides, breake off,
breake off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: By heauen, all drie beaten with pure ſcoffe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell madde Wenches, you haue ſimple
wits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Twentie adieus my frozen Muſcouits.
Are theſe the breed of wits ſo wondred at?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boyet.
SPEECH.LINE: Tapers they are, with your ſweete breathes
puft out

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſa.
SPEECH.LINE: Wel-liking wits they haue, groſſe, groſſe, fat, fat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: O pouertie in wit, Kingly poore flout.
Will they not (thinke you) hang themſelues to night?
Or euer but in vizards ſhew their faces:
This pert Berowne was out of count’nance quite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſa.
SPEECH.LINE: They were all in lamentable caſes.
The King was weeping ripe for a good word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Berowne did ſweare himſelfe out of all ſuite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Dumaine was at my ſeruice, and his ſword:
No point (quoth I:) my ſeruant ſtraight was mute.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ka.
SPEECH.LINE: Lord Longauill ſaid I came ore his hart:
And trow you what he call’d me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Qualme perhaps.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes in good faith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Go ſickneſſe as thou art.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, better wits haue worne plain ſtatute caps,
But will you heare; the King is my loue ſworne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: And quicke Berowne hath plighted faith to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: And Longauill was for my ſeruice borne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Dumaine is mine as ſure as barke on tree.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boyet.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, and prettie miſtreſſes giue eare,
Immediately they will againe be heere
In their owne ſhapes: for it can neuer be,
They will digeſt this harſh indignitie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Will they returne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: They will they will, God knowes,
And leape for ioy, though they are lame with blowes:
Therefore change Fauours, and when they repaire,
Blow like ſweet Roſes, in this ſummer aire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: How blow? how blow? Speake to bee vnder-
ſtood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Faire Ladies maskt, are Roſes in their bud:
Diſmaskt, their damaske ſweet commixture ſhowne,
Are Angels vailing clouds, or Roſes blowne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Auant perplexitie: What ſhall we do,
If they returne in their owne ſhapes to wo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſa.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Madam, if by me you’l be aduis’d.
Let’s mocke them ſtill as well knowne as diſguis’d:
Let vs complaine to them what fooles were heare,
Diſguis’d like Muſcouites in ſhapeleſſe geare:
And wonder what they were, and to what end
Their ſhallow ſhowes, and Prologue vildely pen’d:
And their rough carriage ſo ridiculous,
Should be preſented at our Tent to vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boyet.
SPEECH.LINE: Ladies, withdraw: the gallants are at hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quee.
SPEECH.LINE: Whip to our Tents, as Rœs runnes ore Land.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the King and the reſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Faire ſir, God ſaue you. Wher’s the Princeſſe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Gone to her Tent.
Pleaſe it your Maieſtie command me any ſeruice to her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: That ſhe vouchſafe me audience for one word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy
SPEECH.LINE: I will, and ſo will ſhe, I know my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: This fellow pickes vp wit as Pigeons peaſe,
And vtters it againe, when Ioue doth pleaſe.
He is Wits Pedler, and retailes his Wares,
At Wakes, and Waſſels, Meetings, Markets, Faires.
And we that ſell by groſſe, the Lord doth know,
Haue not the grace to grace it with ſuch ſhow.
This Gallant pins the Wenches on his ſleeue.
Had he bin Adam, he had tempted Eue.
He can carue too, and liſpe: Why this is he,
That kiſt away his hand in courteſie.
This is the Ape of Forme, Monſieur the nice,
That when he plaies at Tables, chides the Dice
In honorable tearmes: Nay he can ſing
A meane moſt meanly, and in Vſhering
Mend him who can: the Ladies call him ſweete.
The ſtaires as he treads on them kiſſe his feete.
This is the flower that ſmiles on euerie one,
To ſhew his teeth as white as Whales bone.
And conſciences that wil not die in debt,
Pay him the dutie of honie-tongued Boyet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: A bliſter on his ſweet tongue with my hart,
That put Armathœs Page out of his part.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: See where it comes. Behauiour what wer’t thou,
Till this madman ſhew’d thee? And what art thou now?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: All haile ſweet Madame, and faire time of day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Faire in all Haile is foule, as I conceiue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Conſtrue my ſpeeches better, if you may.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Then wiſh me better, I wil giue you leaue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: We came to viſit you, and purpoſe now
To leade you to our Court, vouchſafe it then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: This field ſhal hold me, and ſo hold your vow:
Nor God, nor I, delights in periur’d men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Rebuke me not for that which you prouoke:
The vertue of your eie muſt breake my oth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Q.
SPEECH.LINE: You nickname vertue: vice you ſhould haue ſpoke:
For vertues office neuer breakes men troth.
Now by my maiden honor, yet as pure
As the vnſallied Lilly, I proteſt,
A world of torments though I ſhould endure,
I would not yeeld to be your houſes gueſt:
So much I hate a breaking cauſe to be
Of heauenly oaths, vow’d with integritie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: O you haue liu’d in deſolation heere,
Vnſeene, vnuiſited, much to our ſhame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Not ſo my Lord, it is not ſo I ſweare,
We haue had paſtimes heere, and pleaſant game,
A meſſe of Ruſſians left vs but of late.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: How Madam? Ruſsians?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: I in truth, my Lord.
Trim gallants, full of Courtſhip and of ſtate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſa.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam ſpeake true. It is not ſo my Lord:
My Ladie (to the manner of the daies)
In curteſie giues vndeſeruing praiſe.
We foure indeed confronted were with foure
In Ruſsia habit: Heere they ſtayed an houre,
And talk’d apace: and in that houre (my Lord)
They did not bleſſe vs with one happy word.
I dare not call them fooles; but this I thinke,
When they are thirſtie, fooles would faine haue drinke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: This ieſt is drie to me. Gentle ſweete,
Your wits makes wiſe things fooliſh when we greete
With eies beſt ſeeing, heauens fierie eie:
By light we looſe light; your capacitie
Is of that nature, that to your huge ſtoore,
Wiſe things ſeeme fooliſh, and rich things but poore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: This proues you wiſe and rich: for in my eie

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: I am a foole, and full of pouertie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: But that you take what doth to you belong,
It were a fault to ſnatch words from my tongue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: O, I am yours, and all that I poſſeſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: All the foole mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot giue you leſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Which of the Vizards what it that you wore?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Where? when? What Vizard?
Why demand you this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: There, then, that vizard, that ſuperfluous caſe,
That hid the worſe, and ſhew’d the better face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: We are diſcried,
They’l mocke vs now downeright.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: Let vs confeſſe, and turne it to a ieſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Que.
SPEECH.LINE: Amaz’d my Lord? Why lookes your Highnes ſadde?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſa.
SPEECH.LINE: Helpe hold his browes, hee’l ſound: why looke
you pale?
Sea-ſicke I thinke comming from Muſcouie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Thus poure the ſtars down plagues for periury.
Can any face of braſſe hold longer out?
Heere ſtand I, Ladie dart thy skill at me,
Bruiſe me with ſcorne, confound me with a flout.
Thruſt thy ſharpe wit quite through my ignorance.
Cut me to peeces with thy keene conceit:
And I will wiſh thee neuer more to dance,
Nor neuer more in Ruſsian habit waite.
O! neuer will I truſt to ſpeeches pen’d,
Nor to the motion of a Schoole-boies tongue.
Nor neuer come in vizard to my friend,
Nor woo in rime like a blind-harpers ſongue,
Taffata phraſes, ſilken tearmes preciſe,
Three-pil’d Hyperboles, ſpruce affeƈtion;
Figures pedanticall, theſe ſummer flies,
Haue blowne me full of maggot oſtentation.
I do forſweare them, and I heere proteſt,
By this white Gloue (how white the hand God knows)
Henceforth my woing minde ſhall be expreſt
In ruſſet yeas, and honeſt kerſie nœs.
And to begin Wench, ſo God helpe me law,
My loue to thee is ſound, ſans cracke or flaw,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſa.
SPEECH.LINE: Sans, ſans, I pray you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet I haue a tricke
Of the old rage: beare with me, I am ſicke.
Ile leaue it by degrees: ſoft, let vs ſee,
Write Lord haue mercie on vs, on thoſe three,
They are infeƈted, in their hearts it lies:
They haue the plague, and caught it of your eyes:
Theſe Lords are viſited, you are not free:
For the Lords tokens on you do I ſee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: No, they are free that gaue theſe tokens to vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Our ſtates are forfeit, ſeeke not to vndo vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: It is not ſo; for how can this be true,
That you ſtand forfeit, being thoſe that ſue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, for I will not haue to do with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor ſhall not, if I do as I intend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Speake for your ſelues, my wit is at an end.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Teach vs ſweete Madame, for our rude tranſ-
greſsion, ſome faire excuſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: The faireſt is confeſsion.
Were you not heere but euen now, diſguis’d?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, I was.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: And were you well aduis’d?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: I was faire Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: When you then were heere,
What did you whiſper in your Ladies eare?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: That more then all the world I did reſpeƈt her

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: When ſhee ſhall challenge this, you will reieƈt
her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Vpon mine Honor no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, peace, forbeare:
Your oath once broke, you force not to forſweare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Deſpiſe me when I breake this oath of mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: I will, and therefore keepe it. Roſaline,
What did the Ruſsian whiſper in your eare?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, he ſwore that he did hold me deare
As precious eye-ſight, and did value me
Aboue this World: adding thereto moreouer,
That he would Wed me, or elſe die my Louer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: God giue thee ioy of him: the Noble Lord
Moſt honorably doth vphold his word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: What meane you Madame?
By my life, my troth
I neuer ſwore this Ladie ſuch an oth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: By heauen you did; and to confirme it plaine,
You gaue me this: But take it ſir againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: My faith and this, the Princeſſe I did giue,
I knew her by this Iewell on her ſleeue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon me ſir, this Iewell did ſhe weare.
And Lord Berowne (I thanke him) is my deare.
What? Will you haue me, or your Pearle againe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Neither of either, I remit both twaine.
I ſee the tricke on’t: Heere was a conſent,
Knowing aforehand of our merriment,
To daſh it like a Chriſtmas Comedie.
Some carry-tale, ſome pleaſe-man, ſome ſlight Zanie,
Some mumble-newes, ſome trencher-knight, ſom Dick
That ſmiles his cheeke in yeares, and knowes the trick
To make my Lady laugh, when ſhe’s diſpos’d;
Told our intents before: which once diſclos’d,
The Ladies did change Fauours; and then we
Following the ſignes, woo’d but the ſigne of ſhe.
Now to our periurie, to adde more terror,
We are againe forſworne in will and error.
Much vpon this tis: and might not you
Foreſtall our ſport, to make vs thus vntrue?
Do not you know my Ladies foot by’th ſquier?
And laugh vpon the apple of her eie?
And ſtand betweene her backe ſir, and the fire,
Holding a trencher, ieſting merrilie?
You put our Page out: go, you are alowd.
Die when you will, a ſmocke ſhall be your ſhrowd.
You leere vpon me, do you? There’s an eie
Wounds like a Leaden ſword.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Full merrily hath this braue manager, this car-
reere bene run.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Lœ, he is tilting ſtraight. Peace, I haue don.
Welcome pure wit, thou part’ſt a faire fray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: O Lord ſir, they would kno,
Whether the three worthies ſhall come in, or no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: What, are there but three?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: No ſir, but it is vara fine,
For euerie one purſents three.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: And three times thrice is nine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Not ſo ſir, vnder correƈtion ſir, I hope it is not ſo.
You cannot beg vs ſir, I can aſſure you ſir, we know what we know:
I hope ſir three times thrice ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Is not nine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Vnder correƈtion ſir, wee know where-vntill it
doth amount.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: By Ioue, I alwaies tooke three threes for nine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: O Lord ſir, it were pittie you ſhould get your
liuing by reckning ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: How much is it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: O Lord ſir, the parties themſelues, the aƈtors ſir
will ſhew where-vntill it doth amount: for mine owne
part, I am (as they ſay, but to perfeƈt one man in one
poore man) Pompion the great ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Art thou one of the Worthies?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I t pleaſed them to thinke me worthie of Pompey
the great: for mine owne part, I know not the degree of
the Worthie, but I am to ſtand for him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber
SPEECH.LINE: Go, bid them prepare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: We will turne it finely off ſir, we wil take ſome
care.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Berowne, they will ſhame vs:
Let them not approach.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: We are ſhame-proofe my Lord: and ’tis ſome
policie, to haue one ſhew worſe then the Kings and his
companie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſay they ſhall not come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay my good Lord, let me ore-rule you now;
That ſport beſt pleaſes, that doth leaſt know how.
Where Zeale ſtriues to content, and the contents
Dies in the Zeale of that which it preſents:
Their forme confounded, makes moſt forme in mirth,
When great things labouring periſh in their birth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: A right deſcription of our ſport my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Annointed, I implore ſo much expence of thy
royall ſweet breath, as will vtter a brace of words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Doth this man ſerue God?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Why aske you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: He ſpeak’s not like a man of God’s making.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: That’s all one my faire ſweet honie Monarch:
For I proteſt, the Schoolmaſter is exceeding fantaſticall:
Too too vaine, too too vaine. But we wil put it (as they
ſay) to Fortuna delaguar, I wiſh you the peace of minde
moſt royall cupplement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Here is like to be a good preſence of Worthies;
He preſents Heƈtor of Troy, the Swaine Pompey ý great,
the Pariſh Curate Alexander, Armadœs Page Hercules,
the Pedant Iudas Machabeus: and if theſe foure Wor-
thies in their firſt ſhew thriue, theſe foure will change
habites, and preſent the other fiue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: There is fiue in the firſt ſhew.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: You are deceiued, tis not ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: The Pedant, the Braggart, the Hedge-Prieſt, the
Foole, and the Boy,
Abate throw at Novum, and the whole world againe,
Cannot pricke out fiue ſuch, take each one in’s vaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: The ſhip is vnder ſaile, and here ſhe coms amain.

LINE.ITALIC: I Pompey am.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: You lie, you are not he.

LINE.ITALIC: I Pompey am.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: With Libbards head on knee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Well ſaid old mocker,
I muſt needs be friends with thee.

LINE.ITALIC: I Pompey am, Pompey ſurnam’d the big.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: The great.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: It is great ſir: Pompey ſurnam’d the great:

LINE.ITALIC: That oft in field, with Targe and Shield,
did make my fœ to ſweat:
And trauailing along this coaſt, I heere am come by chance,
And lay my Armes before the legs of this ſweet Laſſe of
France.

SPEECH.LINE: If your Ladiſhip would ſay thankes Pompey, I had done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Great thankes great Pompey.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Tis not ſo much worth: but I hope I was per-
feƈt. I made a little fault in great.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: My hat to a halfe-penie, Pompey prooues the
beſt Worthie.

LINE.ITALIC: When in the world I liu’d, I was the worldes Com-
mander:
By Eaſt, Weſt, North, & South, I ſpred my conquering might
My Scutcheon plaine declares that I am Aliſander.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boiet.
SPEECH.LINE: Your noſe ſaies no, you are not:
For it ſtands too right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Your noſe ſmells no, in this moſt tender ſmel-
ling Knight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: The Conqueror is diſmaid:
Proceede good Alexander.

LINE.ITALIC: When in the world I liued, I was the worldes Com-
mander.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boiet.
SPEECH.LINE: Moſt true, ’tis right; you were ſo Aliſander.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Pompey the great.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: your ſeruant and Coſtard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Take away the Conqueror, take away Aliſander

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: O ſir, you haue ouerthrowne Aliſander the con-
queror: you will be ſcrap’d out of the painted cloth for
this: your Lion that holds his Pollax ſitting on a cloſe
ſtoole, will be giuen to Aiax. He will be the ninth wor-
thie. A Conqueror, and affraid to ſpeake? Runne away
for ſhame Aliſander. There an’t ſhall pleaſe you: a foo-
liſh milde man, an honeſt man, looke you, & ſoon daſht.
He is a maruellous good neighbour inſooth, and a verie
good Bowler: but for Aliſander, alas you ſee, how ’tis a
little ore-parted. But there are Worthies a comming,
will ſpeake their minde in ſome other ſort.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Stand aſide good Pompey.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Pedant for Iudas, and the Boy for Hercules.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: Great Hercules is preſented by this Impe,
Whoſe Club kil’d Cerberus that three-headed Canus,
And when he was a babe, a childe, a ſhrimpe,
Thus did he ſtrangle Serpents in his Manus:
Quoniam, he ſeemeth in minoritie,
Ergo, I come with this Apologie.
Keepe ſome ſtate in thy exit, and vaniſh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: Iudas I am.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: A Iudas?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.

LINE.ITALIC: Not Iſcariot ſir.

SPEECH.LINE: Iudas I am, ycliped Machabeus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: Iudas Machabeus clipt, is plaine Iudas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: A kiſsing traitor. How art thou prou’dIudas?

LINE.ITALIC: Iudas I am.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: The more ſhame for you Iudas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: What meane you ſir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boi.
SPEECH.LINE: To make Iudas hang himſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: Begin ſir, you are my elder.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Well follow’d, Iudas was hang’d on an Elder.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: I will not be put out of countenance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Becauſe thou haſt no face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: What is this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boi.
SPEECH.LINE: A Citterne head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: The head of a bodkin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: A deaths face in a ring.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lon.
SPEECH.LINE: The face of an old Roman coine, ſcarce ſeene.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boi.
SPEECH.LINE: The pummell of Caeſars Faulchion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: The caru’d-bone face on a Flaske.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: S[aint]. Georges halfe cheeke in a brooch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and in a brooch of Lead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and worne in the cap of a Tooth-drawer.
And now forward, for we haue put thee in countenance

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue put me out of countenance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Falſe, we haue giuen thee faces.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: But you haue out-fac’d them all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: And thou wer’t a Lion, we would do ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Therefore as he is, an Aſſe, let him go:
And ſo adieu ſweet Iude. Nay, why doſt thou ſtay?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: For the latter end of his name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: For the Aſſe to the Iude: giue it him. Iud-as a-
way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: This is not generous, not gentle, not humble.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: A light for monſieur Iudas, it growes darke, he
may ſtumble.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Que.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas poore Machabeus, how hath hee beene
baited.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Hide thy head Achilles, heere comes Heƈtor in
Armes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: Though my mockes come home by me, I will
now be merrie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Hector was but a Troyan in reſpeƈt of this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boi.
SPEECH.LINE: But is this Heƈtor?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke Heƈtor was not ſo cleane timber’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lon.
SPEECH.LINE: His legge is too big for Heƈtor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: More Calfe certaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boi.
SPEECH.LINE: No, he is beſt indued in the ſmall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: This cannot be Heƈtor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: He’s a God or a Painter, for he makes faces.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.

LINE.ITALIC: The Armipotent Mars, of Launces the almighty,

SPEECH.LINE: gaue Heƈtor a gift.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: A gilt Nutmegge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: A Lemmon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lon.
SPEECH.LINE: Stucke with Cloues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: No clouen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.

LINE.ITALIC: The Armipotent Mars of Launces the almighty,
Gaue Heƈtor a gift, the heire of Illion;
A man ſo breathed, that certaine he would fight: yea
From morne till night, out of his Pauillion.

SPEECH.LINE: I am that Flower.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: That Mint.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Long.
SPEECH.LINE: That Cullambine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet Lord Longauill reine thy tongue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lon.
SPEECH.LINE: I muſt rather giue it the reine: for it runnes a-
gainſt Heƈtor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and Heƈtor’s a Grey-hound.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: The ſweet War-man is dead and rotten,
Sweet chuckes, beat not the bones of the buried:
But I will forward with my deuice;
Sweete Royaltie beſtow on me the ſence of hearing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Speake braue Heƈtor, we are much delighted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: i do adore thy ſweet Graces ſlipper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Loues her by the foot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: He may not by the yard.

LINE.ITALIC: This Heƈtor farre ſurmounted Hanniball.
The partie is gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Fellow Heƈtor, ſhe is gone; ſhe is two moneths
on her way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: What meaneſt thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith vnleſſe you play the honeſt Troyan,
the poore Wench is caſt away: ſhe’s quick, the child brags
in her belly alreadie: tis yours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Doſt thou infamonize me among Potentates?
Thou ſhalt die.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Then ſhall Heƈtor be whipt for Iaquenetta that
is quicke by him, and hang’d for Pompey, that is dead by
him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: Moſt rare Pompey.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boi.
SPEECH.LINE: Renowned Pompey.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Greater then great, great, great, great Pompey:
Pompey the huge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: Heƈtor trembles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Pompey is moued, more Atees more Atees ſtirre
them, or ſtirre them on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: Heƈtor will challenge him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: I, if a’haue no more mans blood in’s belly, then
will ſup a Flea.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: By the North-pole I do challenge thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I wil not fight with a pole like a Northern man;
Ile ſlaſh, Ile do it by the ſword: I pray you let mee bor-
row my Armes againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: Roome for the incenſed Worthies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile do it in my ſhirt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: Moſt reſolute Pompey.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Maſter, let me take you a button hole lower:
Do you not ſee Pompey is vncaſing for the combat: what
meane you? you will loſe your reputation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Gentlemen and Souldiers pardon me, I will
not combat in my ſhirt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: You may not denie it, Pompey hath made the
challenge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet bloods, I both may, and will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: What reaſon haue you for’t?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: The naked truth of it is, I haue no ſhirt,
I go woolward for penance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: True, and it was inioyned him in Rome for want
of Linnen: ſince when, Ile be ſworne he wore none, but
a diſhclout of Iaquenettas, and that hee weares next his
heart for a fauour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: God ſaue you Madame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome Marcade, but that thou interrupteſt
our merriment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Marc.
SPEECH.LINE: I am ſorrie Madam, for the newes I bring is
heauie in my tongue. The King your father

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Dead for my life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Euen ſo: My tale is told.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Worthies away, the Scene begins to cloud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: For mine owne part, I breath free breath: I
haue ſeene the day of wrong, through the little hole of
diſcretion, and I will right my ſelfe like a Souldier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: How fare’s your Maieſtie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Boyet prepare, I will away to night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Madame not ſo, I do beſeech you ſtay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Prepare I ſay. I thanke you gracious Lords
For all your faire endeuours and entreats:
Out of a new ſad-ſoule, that you vouchſafe,
In your rich wiſedome to excuſe, or hide,
The liberall oppoſition of our ſpirits,
If ouer-boldly we haue borne our ſelues,
In the conuerſe of breath (your gentleneſſe
Was guiltie of it.) Farewell worthie Lord:
A heauie heart beares not a humble tongue.
Excuſe me ſo, comming ſo ſhort of thankes,
For my great ſuite, ſo eaſily obtain’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: The extreme parts of time, extremelie formes
All cauſes to the purpoſe of his ſpeed:
And often at his verie looſe decides
That, which long proceſſe could not arbitrate.
And though the mourning brow of progenie
Forbid the ſmiling curteſie of Loue:
The holy ſuite which faine it would conuince,
Yet ſince loues argument was firſt on foote,
Let not the cloud of ſorrow iuſtle it
From what it purpos’d: ſince to waile friends loſt,
Is not by much ſo wholſome profitable,
As to reioyce at friends but newly found.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: I vnderſtand you not, my greefes are double.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Honeſt plain words, beſt pierce the ears of griefe
And by theſe badges vnderſtand the King,
For your faire ſakes haue we negleƈted time,
Plaid foule play with our oaths: your beautie Ladies
Hath much deformed vs, faſhioning our humors
Euen to the oppoſed end of our intents.
And what in vs hath ſeem’d ridiculous:
As Loue is full of vnbefitting ſtraines,
All wanton as a childe, skipping and vaine.
Form’d by the eie, and therefore like the eie.
Full of ſtraying ſhapes, of habits, and of formes
Varying in ſubieƈts as the eie doth roule,
To euerie varied obieƈt in his glance:
Which partie-coated preſence of looſe loue
Put on by vs, if in your heauenly eies,
Haue misbecom’d our oathes and grauities.
Thoſe heauenlie eies that looke into theſe faults,
Suggeſted vs to make: therefore Ladies
Our loue being yours, the error that Loue makes
Is likewiſe yours. We to our ſelues proue falſe,
By being once falſe, for euer to be true
To thoſe that make vs both, faire Ladies you.
And euen that falſhood in it ſelfe a ſinne,
Thus purifies it ſelfe, and turnes to grace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: We haue receiu’d your Letters, full of Loue:
Your Fauours, the Ambaſſadors of Loue.
And in our maiden counſaile rated them,
At courtſhip, pleaſant ieſt, and curteſie,
As bumbaſt and as lining to the time:
But more deuout then theſe are our reſpeƈts
Haue we not bene, and therefore met your loues
In their owne faſhion, like a merriment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: Our letters Madam, ſhew’d much more then ieſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lon.
SPEECH.LINE: So did our lookes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſa.
SPEECH.LINE: We did not coat them ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Now at the lateſt minute of the houre,
Grant vs your loues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: A time me thinkes too ſhort,
To make a world-without-end bargaine in:
No, no my Lord, your Grace is periur’d much,
Full of deare guiltineſſe, and therefore this:
If for my Loue (as there is no ſuch cauſe)
You will do ought, this ſhall you do for me.
Your oth I will not truſt: but go with ſpeed
To ſome forlorne and naked Hermitage,
Remote from all the pleaſures of the world:
There ſtay, vntill the twelue Celeſtiall Signes
Haue brought about their annuall reckoning.
If this auſtere inſociable life,
Change not your offer made in heate of blood:
If froſts, and faſts, hard lodging, and thin weeds
Nip not the gaudie bloſſomes of your Loue,
But that it beare this triall, and laſt loue:
Then at the expiration of the yeare,
Come challenge me, challenge me by theſe deſerts,
And by this Virgin palme, now kiſſing thine,
I will be thine: and till that inſtant ſhut
My wofull ſelfe vp in a mourning houſe,
Raining the teares of lamentation,
For the remembrance of my Fathers death.
If this thou do denie, let our hands part,
Neither intitled in the others hart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: If this, or more then this, I would denie,
To flatter vp theſe powers of mine with reſt,
The ſodaine hand of death cloſe vp mine eie.
Hence euer then, my heart is in thy breſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: And what to me my Loue? and what to me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: You muſt be purged too, your ſins are rack’d.
You are attaint with faults and periurie:
Therefore if you my fauor meane to get,
A tweluemonth ſhall you ſpend, and neuer reſt,
But ſeeke the wearie beds of people ſicke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: But what to me my loue? but what to me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: A wife? a beard, faire health, and honeſtie,
With three-fold loue, I wiſh you all theſe three.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: O ſhall I ſay, I thanke you gentle wife?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: Not ſo my Lord, a tweluemonth and a day,
Ile marke no words that ſmoothfac’d woœrs ſay.
Come when the King doth to my Ladie come:
Then if I haue much loue, Ile giue you ſome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile ſerue thee true and faithfully till then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kath.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet ſweare not, leaſt ye be forſworne agen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lon.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſaies Maria?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mari.
SPEECH.LINE: At the tweluemonths end,
Ile change my blacke Gowne, for a faithfull friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lon.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile ſtay with patience: but the time is long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mari.
SPEECH.LINE: The liker you, few taller are ſo yong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Studies my Ladie? Miſtreſſe, looke on me,
Behold the window of my heart, mine eie:
What humble ſuite attends thy anſwer there,
Impoſe ſome ſeruice on me for my loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Oft haue I heard of you my Lord Berowne,
Before I ſaw you: and the worlds large tongue
Proclaimes you for a man repleate with mockes,
Full of compariſons, and wounding floutes:
Which you on all eſtates will execute,
That lie within the mercie of your wit.
To weed this Wormewood from your fruitfull braine,
And therewithall to win me, if you pleaſe,
Without the which I am not to be won:
You ſhall this tweluemonth terme from day to day,
Viſit the ſpeechleſſe ſicke, and ſtill conuerſe
With groaning wretches: and your taske ſhall be,
With all the fierce endeuour of your wit,
To enforce the pained impotent to ſmile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: To moue wilde laughter in the throate of death?
It cannot be, it is impoſſible.
Mirth cannot moue a ſoule in agonie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Why that’s the way to choke a gibing ſpirit,
Whoſe influence is begot of that looſe grace,
Which ſhallow laughing hearers giue to fooles:
A ieſts proſperitie, lies in the eare
Of him that heares it, neuer in the tongue
Of him that makes it: then, if ſickly eares,
Deaft with the clamors of their owne deare grones,
Will heare your idle ſcornes; continue then,
And I will haue you, and that fault withall.
But if they will not, throw away that ſpirit,
And I ſhal finde you emptie of that fault,
Right ioyfull of your reformation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: A tweluemonth? Well: befall what will befall,
Ile ieſt a tweluemonth in an Hoſpitall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſweet my Lord, and ſo I take my leaue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: No Madam, we will bring you on your way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Our woing doth not end like an old Play:
Iacke hath not Gill: theſe Ladies courteſie
Might wel haue made our ſport a Comedie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Come ſir, it wants a tweluemonth and a day,
And then ’twil end.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: That’s too long for a play.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet Maieſty vouchſafe me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Was not that Heƈtor?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: The worthie Knight of Troy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: I wil kiſſe thy royal finger, and take leaue.
I am a Votarie, I haue vow’d to Iaquenetta to holde the
Plough for her ſweet loue three yeares. But moſt eſtee-
med greatneſſe, wil you heare the Dialogue that the two
Learned men haue compiled, in praiſe of the Owle and
the Cuckow? It ſhould haue followed in the end of our
ſhew.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Call them forth quickely, we will do ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Holla, Approach.
This ſide is Hiems, Winter.
This Ver, the Spring: the one maintained by the Owle,
Th’other by the Cuckow.
Ver, begin.
When Daſies pied, and Violets blew,
And Cuckow-buds of yellow hew:
And Ladie-ſmockes all ſiluer white,
Do paint the Medowes with delight.
The Cuckow then on euerie tree,
Mockes married men, for thus ſings he,
Cuckow.
Cuckow, Cuckow: O word of feare,
Vnpleaſing to a married eare.
When Shepheards pipe on Oaten ſtrawes,
And merrie Larkes are Ploughmens clockes:
When Turtles tread, and Rookes and Dawes,
And Maidens bleach their ſummer ſmockes:
The Cuckow then on euerie tree
Mockes married men; for thus ſings he,
Cuckow.
Cuckow, Cuckow: O word of feare,
Vnpleaſing to a married eare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Winter.
SPEECH.LINE: When Iſicles hang by the wall,
And Dicke the Shepheard blowes his naile;
And Tom beares Logges into the hall,
And Milke comes frozen home in paile:
When blood is nipt, and waies be fowle,
Then nightly ſings the ſtaring Owle
Tu-whit to-who.
A merrie note,
While greaſie Ione doth keele the pot.
When all aloud the winde doth blow,
And coffing drownes the Parſons ſaw:
And birds ſit brooding in the ſnow,
And Marrians noſe lookes red and raw:
When roaſted Crabs hiſſe in the bowle,
Then nightly ſings the ſtaring Owle,
Tu-whit to-who:
A merrie note,
While greaſie Ione doth keele the pot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: The Words of Mercurie,
Are harſh after the ſongs of Apollo:
You that way; we this way.
